trans:
Gallop
Gallop is an unsymmetrical three-beat walk or run of the horse. A saddle horse can gallop from the right or left leg. It depends on which pair of limbs moves forward. Most animals start from the inside pair of legs. Otherwise, such a horse walk is called counter-gallop. Gallop also features jumps.
This walk also has four types:
working gallop;
intermediate gallop;
collected gallop;
stretched gallop.
Ride
Ride is the fastest method of movement of saddle horses - a form of stretched gallop. This horse walk is unsymmetrical, four-beat. Hoofs touch the ground as follows: left back, right back, left front, right front followed by the flight phase. During this phase, both legs do not come in contact with the ground.
Other types of walks
There are also two types of horse walks that beginners might be not familiar with. These are:
Pace - symmetrical, two-beat walk which consists in simultaneous raising both legs from the same side of the body. The sequence of limb movement is as follows: left front and left back, right front and right back.
